content.description: This deceptively challenging slab corner climb will have even the bravest climber sweating through their pants. Filled with difficult compression as well as devious slopers, this is one boulder you won't want to miss. The crux consists of a difficult squat on slippery granite, followed by a large sloper leading to a quartz top-out. Be careful not to fall, the Splitting Maul is not very forgiving...
content.protection: Soft forest floor (loam) , somewhat cramped, be sure to bring at least 2 mats
content.location: The start is near the bottom about 3.5 feet from the ground. It is clearly visible on a very large granite glacial boulder, which sits about 20 feet off the right of the trail heading up the mountain.

content.description: A big granite mantle followed by... another big granite mantle. A great climb for beginners with soft granite holds to start and a nice shelf to finish on.
content.protection: once again space is limited but overall a very safe boulder
content.location: On the same rock as "Splitting Maul", start is a few feet further to the left of the highest corner (the right one), with the hands matching in a deep diagonal crack.

content.description: A short but challenging climb with a radically difficult crouching start followed by a series of painful crack-wedging crimps, into a top out/mantle to a small granite slab.
content.protection: a relatively clear forest floor surrounds this boulder, due to it's deceptively short length and relative difficulty multiple mats may be helpful
content.location: about 250 east of the main and largest rock in the area, often mossy from the trail, the climbing face is on the east/south-east face, the start is on the lowest quartzite crack with both hands

content.description: A large glacial deposit of granite boulders lined with quartz ribbons, strewn about an old growth hardwood forest. Conditions are often damp, and boulders may be mossy. Most routes are short, offering a challenging variety of holds.
